q1.text: What percentage of your daily schedule is dictated by external deadlines, alarms, or societal expectations?

responses.a: You seem to have minimal external control. Do you think this is freedom, or are you just out-of-touch?
responses.b: Moderate compliance with societal rhythms detected. You’re playing along well, but could you be better?
responses.c: Close syncing to the system detected. It must be comforting to have your life dictated for you.
responses.d: Perfect adherence to external demands detected. Your time isn’t yours—it’s rented out hourly.

q1.reflection: Ever notice how your schedule isn’t really your own? If you didn’t have deadlines, what would you do with your time?

q2.text: How many hours per day do you dedicate to activities with measurable outcomes (e.g., work, chores, studying)?

responses.a: Two hours? Bold. You might call that living, but society calls it lazy.
responses.b: Respectable effort. Just enough productivity to stay useful in the game.
responses.c: Impressive grind. Productivity must be your only friend.
responses.d: 9+ hours? I wonder who's really paying for all that overtime.

q2.reflection: Imagine if productivity wasn’t tied to your value. Would you work less, or would you work differently?

q3.text: How often do you feel guilty for ‘wasting’ time in a single day?

responses.a: No guilt? Revolutionary. You should probably get that fixed.
responses.b: Occasional guilt is healthy. Just enough shame to keep you productive.
responses.c: Wow, you’re driven by guilt. Imagine being in control of your own life.
responses.d: Constant guilt? Are you really just a mindless robot with a stopwatch brain?

q3.reflection: Who decides what counts as ‘wasting’ time? Spoiler: It’s probably not you.

q4.text: How many times a day do you check the time (via clocks, phones, or other devices)?

responses.a: Practically timeless. Are you enlightened, or just a chronically behind?
responses.b: Moderate clock-checking. You’re timely enough but no one's talking about your efficiency.
responses.c: 11-20 times...a little bit more and then you'll actually be running at the standard that you should be.
responses.d: 21+ times? The clock controls you, talk about co-dependent.

q4.reflection: Why does checking the time feel so necessary? What happens if you don’t?

q5.text: When you reflect on your day, do you categorize it by...

responses.a: Meaningful moments? Do you have a secret stash of free time?
responses.b: You’re living in the spreadsheet of life. Does filling your little cells make you happy?
responses.c: Counting waste? Better get a start on repaying all that time debt you've amassed.
responses.d: Your life is survival, not living. If only you could actually be fulfilled by doing everything you 'have to do.'

q5.reflection: Does your day belong to you, or is it just a series of transactions with time?

q6.text: Do you notice time feeling different based on the activity you’re doing?

options.a: No, time feels linear and constant.
options.b: Yes, work drags, and fun flies by.
options.d: Always, and it makes me question everything.

responses.a: Linear time? That’s the official story and perfectly robotic, as all things should be.
responses.b: Work drags, fun flies—classic capitalism. Guess which one still matters more.
responses.c: Ignoring time’s weirdness? That’s peak denial, must be fun to be so compliant.
responses.d: Questioning time? Careful, that’s how revolutions start and nobody wants that.

q6.reflection: If time isn’t constant, why do we treat it like it is? Who benefits from that?
